columns.text: In this exercise, we assess the initial public offering and underpricing.

The act of issuing an initial public offering (IPO) at a price less than its true market value on the public market is known as **underpricing**. When a new share trades above the specified issue price on its trading date, it is underpriced.

## 15.5a 

Underpricing is a cost to a company because when a value of the stock is less than its true market value, **shareholders will incur losses whenever a stock is sold for a price less than its worth**. Every stakeholder issuing the shares suffers a loss due to this.

Prospective buyers will make relatively significant returns at initially using IPOS, but many will also **incur losses in the long term**. Since the demand for shares exceeds the maximum stock available when the price is lower, investors will be unable to acquire all of the securities they demand, and the underwriters will divide the shares among the investors.

## 15.5b 

Since the stockbroker sells all the shares demanded to encourage investment, the issuance might be considerably **underpriced**.

However, when the price is too low, the issuance is often oversubscribed, or demand for the security exceeds supply. **Thus, this issuance will not be underpriced.** This implies that investors cannot purchase all the shares they demand, and the underwriter will distribute the shares to the shareholders.
